div.l: A lytul Iape that fille in oure citee
Oure oost answerde ⁊and seide I gᵃraunt it þe
Now telle on Roger loke þat it be gode
For mony a pastehastpaste astpaste hast þou leten blode
And mony a Iakk a doủere hast þu sold
That hath ben twies hoot ⁊and twies coold
Of mony pilgryme hastow cristes curs
For of þy persely ȝet fare þei þe wors
That þey haue eten with þy stubbul goos
For in þy shop is mony a flye loos
Now telle on gentil Roger by þy name
But yt y pray þe be not wroth for game
A man may ful soþe in game ⁊and playe
Thou saist ful soth quod Roger by my faye
But soth play quade play as þe flemyng saith
And þ̉erfore henry baillif by thy faiþe
Be not wroth er we deꝑparten here
Thogh þat my tale be of an Ostelerie
But natheles I wilnot tellen it ȝete
But or we part I wis þᵘou shalt be quyte
And þ̉erwith alle loghe ⁊and made chere
And saide his tale as he shal aft̉er here

div.l: A Prentis whilom dwellid in oure citee
And of a craft of vitalers was he
Gaillard he was as golfynche in þe schawe
Broun as bery · a ꝓproper short felawe
With lokkes blake I kempt ful fetisly
Daunce he kouþe so wel and Iolyly
That he clepid perkyn reueilloure
He was as ful of loue and ꝑparamour
As is þe hive ful of hony swete
Wel was þe wenche with him myght mete
At eủery bridale wold he synge ⁊and hoppe
He louede bette þe tauerne þan þe shoppe
